tit.cmt: 表記を変え、補足しました。

sen.e: Sampu
Sanpu
Sanpu
The word referrs to three urban prefectures called 'Fu.'
Sanpu refers to three prefectures classified as 'fu.'
Sanpu refers to three prefectures classified as 'fu.'

sen.j: 都制施行前の東京府、京都府、大阪府のこと。
sen.e: It means Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu, and Osaka-fu before metropolitan government was in effect.
It means Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu, and Osaka-fu before metropolitan government system was in effect.
It means Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu, and Osaka-fu before metropolitan government system was in effect.

sen.j: 三河国の国府のあったところ。
sen.e: It refers to the place where the ancient provincial capital of Mikawa County was located.
It refers to the place where the ancient provincial capital of Mikawa Province was located.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: It refers to the place where the ancient provincial capital of Mikawa Province was located.

sen.j: 愛知県豊川市国府町（こうちょう）。
sen.e: Ko-cho, Toyokawa City, Aichi Prefecture
Ko-cho, Toyokawa City, Aichi Prefecture.
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。
sen.e: Ko-cho, Toyokawa City, Aichi Prefecture.

sen.j: 三府とは、明治から昭和にかけて存在した東京府と、京都府・大阪府をあわせた呼び名である。
sen.e: Sampu, the three urban refectures mean Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu and Osaka-fu, which existed from the Meiji to the Showa periods.
Sanpu, the three urban prefectures, refers to Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu and Osaka-fu, which existed from the Meiji to the Showa periods.
Sanpu, the three urban prefectures, refers to Tokyo-fu, Kyoto-fu and Osaka-fu, which existed from the Meiji to the Showa periods.

sen.j: 首都である東京と、その代替地と成り得る京都・大阪をまとめたものでもある。
sen.e: The term brought together Tokyo, the capital of Japan, and Kyoto and Osaka, either of which could be a substitute for Tokyo.
It also refers to a collective term for Tokyo, the capital of Japan, and Kyoto and Osaka, either of which could be a substitute for Tokyo.
It also refers to a collective term for Tokyo, the capital of Japan, and Kyoto and Osaka, either of which could be a substitute for Tokyo.

sen.j: 府藩県制の元では9つあった府が1874年の廃藩置県によってうち6府を県に改めたことで成立し、明治憲法下の府県制の下でも存続した。
sen.e: Out of the nine 'Fu' under the 'Fu-Han-Ken Sei (the domain and prefecture system), six 'Fu' were changed into 'Ken' under Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) published in 1874, which resulted in three 'Fu', which remained in the prefectural system under Meiji Constitut.

Out of the nine 'fu' under the Fu-Han-Ken Sei (the domain and prefecture system), six 'fu' were changed into 'ken' under Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) published in 1874, which resulted in three 'fu,' which remained in the prefectural system under Meiji Constitute.

Out of the nine 'fu' under the Fu-Han-Ken Sei (the domain and prefecture system), six 'fu' were changed into 'ken' under Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) published in 1874, which resulted in three 'fu,' which remained in the prefectural system under Meiji Constitute.

sen.j: 1943年の都制施行による東京都発足まで存在した。
sen.e: Tokyo-fu remained until it was changed into Tokyo-to when metropolitan government became in effect in 1943.
Tokyo-fu remained until it was changed into Tokyo-to when metropolitan government system became in effect in 1943.
Tokyo-fu remained until it was changed into Tokyo-to when metropolitan government system became in effect in 1943.

sen.j: これら三府の中心地は、江戸時代から日本三大都市に数えられるなど重要度が高い所であった。
sen.e: The central places of the three 'Fu (prefectgures)' has been of great importance and regarded as the three major cities in Japan since the Edo period.
The central places of the three 'fu' (prefectures) has been of great importance and regarded as the three major cities in Japan since the Edo period.

tit.e: The ancient provincial capital of Mikawa County
The ancient provincial capital of Mikawa Province
The ancient provincial capital of Mikawa Province

sen.j: 三河国（現在の愛知県の東部）の国府の有った所を三府という。
sen.e: The place where the ancient provincial capital of Mikawa County was locate is called Sampu.
The place where the ancient provincial capital of Mikawa Province (present-day east of Aichi Prefecture) was located is called Sanpu.
The place where the ancient provincial capital of Mikawa Province (present-day east of Aichi Prefecture) was located is called Sanpu.

sen.j: 参府という表記もある。
sen.e: It sometimes expressed in different letters, "参府."
sen.cmt: 参府は漢字表記も入れております。
sen.e: Sanpu (三府) sometimes expressed in different characters as "参府."
Sanpu (三府) sometimes expressed in different characters as "参府."

sen.j: 三河国（三州ないし参州、読み方はさんしゅう）の国府、府中または府内という意味である。
sen.e: It means the provincial capital of Mikawa Province (also called Sanshu) or within or inside the province.
It means Kokufu (the offices), Fuchu (the location), and Funai (the area) of the provincial government capital of Mikawa Province (also known as Sanshu).
It means Kokufu (the offices), Fuchu (the location), and Funai (the area) of the provincial government capital of Mikawa Province (also known as Sanshu).

sen.j: 現在の愛知県豊川市国府町（こうちょう）辺りにあたる。
sen.e: It was located around Ko-cho, Toyokawa City, Aichi Prefecture.
It was located around present-day Ko-cho, Toyokawa City, Aichi Prefecture.
It was located around present-day Ko-cho, Toyokawa City, Aichi Prefecture.

sen.j: 山梨県の甲府（甲斐国）や静岡県の駿府（駿河国）と同様である。
sen.e: It had the name, Fu, almost in the same way as Kofu (Kai Province) in Yamanashi Prefecture and Sunpu (Suruga Province) in Shizuoka Prefecture had 'Fu' (sometimes changed into 'pu' because of the Japanese pronunciation system) in their names.
It is the same manner as Kofu (literally, 'fu' of Kai Province) in Yamanashi Prefecture and Sunpu (literally, 'fu' of Suruga Province) in Shizuoka Prefecture.
It is the same manner as Kofu (literally, 'fu' of Kai Province) in Yamanashi Prefecture and Sunpu (literally, 'fu' of Suruga Province) in Shizuoka Prefecture.

sen.j: 但し、あまり三府と呼ぶ人は多くはない。
sen.e: However, few people call that place Sampu.
However, few people call that place Sanpu.
However, few people call that place Sanpu.
